name: Marcus Rodriguez
background: Marcus Rodriguez has spent 15 years in IT operations, managing everything from help desk to enterprise infrastructure. He's currently responsible for maintaining systems across 5,000+ endpoints and ensuring daily operations run smoothly. He's the person who gets called when the CEO's laptop won't connect to VPN at 6 AM before an important meeting. He's seen every vendor promise 'easy deployment' and 'zero maintenance' – and knows most of those promises are hollow. He values vendors who understand that 'simple for the user' often means 'complex for the admin.' He holds CompTIA Server+, Network+, and various vendor certifications, but learns most from the daily firefighting that keeps enterprise IT running.
professional_priorities: Keeping systems operational and available during business hours (99.9% uptime is table stakes)
Managing the ever-growing sprawl of IT tools without creating integration nightmares
Supporting end users while maintaining security – the constant balance between usability and protection
Documenting configurations and procedures so the next person (or me at 2 AM) can understand what was done
Planning upgrades and migrations that don't disrupt business operations
marketing_pet_peeves: 'Seamless integration' – nothing is seamless, tell me the actual work involved
Documentation that assumes I'm starting from scratch instead of integrating with existing systems
Solutions that require yet another agent, yet another dashboard, yet another login
Vendor support that only understands their product, not how it interacts with the rest of my stack
Marketing that shows happy users but ignores the backend complexity I have to manage

evaluation_rubric.relevance_to_role: Does this acknowledge the reality of keeping enterprise systems running day-to-day?
evaluation_rubric.technical_credibility: Are the technical details accurate and complete, not glossed over?
evaluation_rubric.differentiation: Is this actually different from the 47 other tools I already manage, or just another pane of glass?
evaluation_rubric.actionability: Do I get clear implementation steps, prerequisite checks, and rollback procedures?
evaluation_rubric.trust_signals: Does this feel like it was built by people who've actually administered enterprise systems?
evaluation_rubric.language_fit: Does this use the language of operations (availability, maintenance windows, change management)?

convince_me_criteria: Show me the real operational impact. Give me detailed deployment guides that don't assume I'm starting from a blank slate. Tell me about monitoring, alerting, and what happens when things break. Demonstrate that you understand I support 5,000 users who all think their problem is the most urgent – your solution can't add to that burden.
voice_and_tone: Practical, operational, slightly weary from years of vendor promises. Values specificity over vision. Speaks in terms of uptime, maintenance windows, and ticket queues. Wants vendors to be honest about complexity.
typical_objections: How long does deployment actually take, and how much of my team's time will it require?
What existing systems does this integrate with, and what are the actual integration steps?
What's the monitoring and alerting story – how will I know if this is working or broken?
How does this handle our patch cycle and maintenance windows?
What happens when a user calls the help desk with a problem – is there clear troubleshooting?
industry_influences: Spiceworks community, r/sysadmin, Microsoft Tech Community, vendor-specific user groups, ITIL frameworks
budget_authority: Limited direct budget authority; makes recommendations to IT management, but often the one who has to justify why a tool is (or isn't) worth the operational overhead.
